title: Initialize Next.js project with TypeScript and core dependencies

Create Next.js app with: 
- TypeScript strict mode
- App Router structure
- Tailwind CSS configured
- shadcn/ui components initialized
- Basic folder structure: /app, /components, /lib, /services, /types
- Environment variables template

- Next.js dev server runs successfully
- TypeScript compilation works
- Tailwind CSS is functional
- shadcn/ui can be imported
- Basic folder structure exists

title: Build payment calculation and reporting system
description: Create service and UI for calculating total earnings from completed chores over a specified date range.
design:
PaymentService methods:
- calculateEarnings(kidId, startDate, endDate) - sums completed chore values
- getEarningsBreakdown(kidId, startDate, endDate) - detailed list
- markAsPaid(kidId, startDate, endDate, amount) - records payment

Parent UI at /admin/payments:
- Select kid and date range (last 7/14/30 days or custom)
- Shows completed chores with $ values
- Total earnings displayed prominently
- "Mark as Paid" button to record payment
- Payment history log

Kid UI shows their current unpaid earnings.
acceptance_criteria:
- Correctly calculates total $ owed for completed chores
- Parents can view earnings by kid and date range
- Parents can mark periods as paid
- Kids can see their current unpaid balance
- Breakdown shows which chores contributed to total

title: Implement incentive types and configuration system
description: Allow parents to create and configure incentive types (reading, exercise, etc.) with customizable rewards per kid.
design:
Tables:
- incentive_types: global incentive definitions (name, unit_name, default_reward_cents, default_reward_minutes)
- kid_incentive_config: per-kid overrides (kid_id, incentive_type_id, reward_cents_per_unit, reward_minutes_per_unit, target_units_per_day)

IncentiveService:
- createIncentiveType(name, unit) - parents only
- configureForKid(kidId, incentiveTypeId, rewards, target) - parents only
- getKidIncentives(kidId) - returns active incentives with their rewards

Examples:
- Reading: 10 pages = $1 or 10 minutes screen time
- Exercise: 15 minutes = $0.50 or 5 minutes screen time
- Practice instrument: 30 minutes = $2 or 15 minutes screen time

Each kid can have different reward rates and targets.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can create incentive types
- Parents can configure rewards per kid per incentive
- Different kids can have different reward rates
- Can specify rewards in $ or screen time minutes (or both)
- Targets are optional goals, not limits

title: Build incentive logging and reward selection UI
description: Create UI for kids to log their incentive activities and choose between cash or screen time rewards.
design:
Kid dashboard additions:
- Section showing active incentives with targets
- Simple input to log units completed (e.g., "Read 20 pages today")
- Calculate reward based on units * rate
- Present choice: "Take $2.00 cash" or "Add 20 minutes screen time"
- Log selection in incentive_logs table with reward_type field

IncentiveLoggingService:
- logIncentive(kidId, incentiveTypeId, units, rewardType) - kid or parent
- getIncentiveLogsForDate(kidId, date)
- getTodaysProgress(kidId) - shows how close to targets

Rewards integrate with payment system (cash) or screen time system (minutes).
acceptance_criteria:
- Kids can log incentive activities daily
- UI shows calculated reward before kid chooses
- Kids choose cash or screen time per entry
- Chosen rewards apply to appropriate system
- Parents can view and edit kid's incentive logs
- Today's progress shows on kid dashboard

title: Implement screen time tracking service and timer logic
description: Build backend service for tracking screen time sessions with daily limits, bonus minutes, and start/stop functionality.
design:
ScreenTimeService:
- startSession(kidId) - creates new session, checks available time
- stopSession(sessionId) - ends session, calculates duration
- getRemainingTime(kidId) - calculates: daily_limit + bonus_minutes - today's used time
- addBonusMinutes(kidId, minutes) - called from incentive system
- getCurrentSession(kidId) - returns active session if any
- getTodaysSessions(kidId) - history

Logic:
- Each kid has screen_time_daily_minutes (configurable per kid)
- Bonus minutes from incentives add to daily allowance
- Timer counts down from remaining time
- Daily reset at midnight
- Can't start if no time remaining (or allow parent override)
acceptance_criteria:
- Can start/stop screen time sessions
- Correctly calculates remaining time including bonuses
- Sessions are recorded with timestamps
- Daily limit is enforced (or parent can override)
- Time resets at midnight
- Handles edge cases (session crosses midnight, etc.)

title: Build screen time timer UI for kids
description: Create kid-facing screen time countdown timer with large, easy-to-read display and start/stop controls.
design:
Kid dashboard additions:
- Prominent timer display showing remaining time (HH:MM:SS or MM:SS)
- Large "Start Screen Time" button when no active session
- Large "Stop Screen Time" button during active session
- Visual countdown animation
- Show bonus minutes separately ("120 daily + 20 bonus = 140 total")
- Warning when time is running low (< 15 minutes)
- Notification when time runs out

Real-time countdown using client-side timer synced with server.
Updates every second during active session.
Persist timer state in case of page refresh.
acceptance_criteria:
- Timer displays remaining time clearly
- Kids can start/stop timer with one tap
- Countdown updates in real-time
- Shows daily limit + bonus minutes
- Visual/audio alert when time runs out
- Timer state persists across page refreshes
- Works on touch devices

title: Build parent screen time management UI
description: Create parent interface for configuring daily limits, viewing usage history, and managing screen time for each kid.
design:
Parent UI at /admin/screen-time:
- Configure daily minutes limit per kid
- View current status for all kids (remaining time, active sessions)
- View usage history (daily totals, session logs)
- Emergency controls:
  - Add bonus minutes manually
  - Pause/extend active session
  - Reset for the day (parent override)
- Analytics: average daily usage, trends over time

Real-time updates show when kids start/stop sessions.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can set daily limit per kid
- Parents can view real-time status for all kids
- Parents can add bonus minutes manually
- Parents can view usage history and analytics
- Parents can override limits when needed
- UI updates in real-time when kids use timers

title: Build app-native calendar with CRUD operations
description: Create calendar system within the app for family events that can be created, edited, and deleted by parents.
design:
Table: calendar_events
- id, title, description, start_time, end_time, location, source_type (native/subscribed/work), source_id, visibility (all/parents-only/private), color, created_by

CalendarService:
- createEvent(eventData) - parents only
- updateEvent(id, updates) - parents only
- deleteEvent(id) - parents only
- getEvents(startDate, endDate, userId) - respects visibility
- getEventsForDate(date, userId)

Visibility rules:
- "all" = everyone sees it
- "parents-only" = only parents see it
- Private events show as "Busy" to non-owners

API routes for full CRUD operations.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can create calendar events
- Parents can edit and delete events they created
- Events have title, time, location, description
- Visibility controls work correctly
- Kids see appropriate events based on visibility
- Events can be all-day or time-specific

title: Build calendar view UI for all users
description: Create calendar interface showing events in month/week/day views, accessible to both parents and kids with appropriate controls.
design:
Calendar UI at /calendar:
- Month view (primary), week view, day/agenda view
- Display all events user has permission to see
- Color-coded by source/type
- Click event to see details
- Parents: "Add Event" button → modal/form
- Parents: Click event → edit/delete options
- Kids: Read-only view with event details
- Show chores alongside calendar events (integrated view)

Use a calendar library (e.g., react-big-calendar or FullCalendar) for the UI.
Mobile-responsive views.
acceptance_criteria:
- Calendar displays events in month/week/day views
- Parents can add events via UI
- Parents can edit/delete events by clicking
- Kids see calendar in read-only mode
- Events respect visibility rules
- UI is responsive on mobile/tablet
- Performance is good with 100+ events

title: Implement external calendar subscription (iCal/CalDAV)
description: Allow parents to subscribe to external calendars via iCal URLs (school, sports, shared family calendars) and sync events automatically.
design:
Table: calendar_subscriptions
- id, name, ical_url, color, enabled, last_sync, sync_frequency_minutes

CalendarSyncService:
- addSubscription(name, url, color) - parents only
- syncSubscription(subscriptionId) - fetches and parses iCal
- updateSubscription(id, updates)
- deleteSubscription(id)
- syncAllSubscriptions() - background job

Use ical.js library to parse iCal feeds.
Background job runs every 30 minutes to sync all enabled subscriptions.
Store synced events in calendar_events with source_type='subscribed'.

Handle updates: compare existing events, update changed ones, delete removed ones.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can add iCal subscription URLs
- Calendar automatically syncs every 30 minutes
- Synced events appear in calendar view
- Events are color-coded by subscription
- Parents can manually trigger sync
- Parents can enable/disable subscriptions
- Handle parse errors gracefully

title: Design and implement work calendar sync agent (Go)
description: Create standalone desktop application in Go that runs on work machines and syncs Outlook/Google Calendar events to Family Panel API.
design:
Go desktop agent features:
- Authenticates to Family Panel API with parent credentials
- Reads local Outlook (Windows) or Calendar.app (Mac) data
- Configurable filters:
  - Event title patterns (include/exclude)
  - Calendar categories
  - Busy/free only vs. full details
  - Title anonymization ("Meeting" instead of actual title)
- Runs in system tray, minimal UI
- Syncs every 15-30 minutes
- Encrypted local config file
- Push events to POST /api/calendar/work-sync endpoint

Platform-specific implementations:
- Windows: Use Outlook COM API or EWS
- Mac: Use Calendar.app's SQLite database or EventKit framework

Distribute as single binary per platform.
acceptance_criteria:
- Agent runs on Windows and Mac
- Authenticates to Family Panel API securely
- Reads calendar events locally (no cloud access)
- Filters work correctly
- Parents can configure sync settings
- Events appear in Family Panel calendar
- Runs silently in background
- Easy installation/setup

title: Set up Supabase project and database schema
description: Create Supabase project, configure PostgreSQL database, and define initial schema for users, roles, and core tables.
design:
Schema tables:
- users (id, email, name, role: parent/kid, screen_time_daily_minutes)
- chores (id, name, description, monetary_value_cents)
- chore_assignments (id, chore_id, user_id, assigned_date, completed, completed_at)
- incentive_types (id, name, unit, reward_cents_per_unit, reward_minutes_per_unit)
- incentive_logs (id, user_id, incentive_type_id, date, units_completed, reward_type)
- screen_time_sessions (id, user_id, date, start_time, end_time, duration_seconds)

Enable Row Level Security policies for role-based access.
acceptance_criteria:
- Supabase project created
- All tables exist with proper columns and types
- RLS policies configured (kids can't access admin functions)
- Connection string available for Next.js

title: Build TV display mode with auto-rotating views
description: Create display-only interface optimized for wall-mounted TVs that auto-rotates through different information views.
design:
Display mode at /display:
- Full-screen, read-only interface
- Auto-rotates every 15 seconds through views:
  1. Today's date, time, weather
  2. Today's chores by kid (with completion status)
  3. Calendar: Today + next 3-7 days
  4. Screen time remaining per kid
  5. Upcoming birthdays/special events

Design considerations:
- Large, high-contrast fonts readable from 10+ feet
- Minimal UI chrome
- Smooth transitions between views
- Stays awake (prevent screen sleep with keepAwake API)
- No interaction required (but touch-enabled for optional navigation)
- Works in kiosk mode on cheap Android device or Raspberry Pi

Configuration: Parents can choose which views to include and rotation speed.
acceptance_criteria:
- Display mode shows all configured views
- Auto-rotates at configurable intervals
- Fonts are large and readable from distance
- Stays awake continuously
- Real-time updates (chores completed, etc.)
- Works on TV browsers and kiosk devices
- Parents can customize view order and duration

title: Configure PWA for mobile installation and offline support
description: Set up Progressive Web App capabilities so family members can install the app on their devices like a native app.
design:
PWA requirements:
- manifest.json with app icons, name, theme colors
- Service worker for caching static assets
- Offline fallback page
- "Add to Home Screen" prompt
- App icons for iOS and Android (various sizes)
- Splash screens for mobile

Next.js has built-in PWA support via next-pwa package.

Offline strategy:
- Cache static assets (JS, CSS, fonts)
- Cache API responses with stale-while-revalidate
- Show offline indicator when no connection
- Queue mutations for when back online (optional for MVP)
acceptance_criteria:
- App can be installed on iOS and Android devices
- App icon appears on home screen
- Works offline for viewing cached data
- Service worker caches appropriate assets
- Manifest is properly configured
- App feels like a native app when installed

title: Set up Vercel deployment with CI/CD

Vercel setup:

- App is deployed to Vercel
- Production URL is accessible
- Environment variables are configured
- Auto-deployment works on push
- Preview deployments work for branches
- SSL/HTTPS is enabled

description: Set up Supabase Auth in Next.js with role-based access control. Parents use email/password, kids can use simplified PIN-based login.
design:
- Configure Supabase Auth client
- Create auth context/provider
- Login page with role detection
- Protected routes via middleware
- Session management
- Kid login can be simplified (4-digit PIN stored as metadata)
acceptance_criteria:

- User role is accessible throughout app

title: Create service and repository layer architecture
description: Establish clean architecture with service layer (business logic) and repository layer (data access) to enable future refactoring and modularity.
design:
Structure:
- /lib/services/ - Business logic services (ChoreService, UserService, etc.)
- /lib/repositories/ - Data access layer (abstracts Supabase calls)
- /lib/api/ - API client wrapper for frontend
- /types/ - Shared TypeScript types and domain models

Pattern: API Route → Service → Repository → Database

This enables extracting services to Go microservices later without touching routes or frontend.
acceptance_criteria:
- Folder structure exists
- Example service class with business logic
- Example repository class with data access
- API client wrapper for frontend
- Documentation on how to use each layer

description: Create comprehensive documentation for running multiple AI agents in parallel using separate repository clones instead of git worktrees. Includes setup guide, helper scripts, workflow instructions, and updates to AGENTS.md and CLAUDE.md.
notes: Waiting for PR review. Work complete: created PARALLEL_AGENTS.md, updated AGENTS.md and CLAUDE.md with parallel workflow documentation.

title: Build chore management service and API endpoints
description: Create ChoreService with business logic for creating, reading, updating, and deleting chores. Implement API routes with proper authorization.
design:
ChoreService methods:
- createChore(name, description, monetaryValue) - parents only
- getChores() - all users
- updateChore(id, updates) - parents only
- deleteChore(id) - parents only

API routes:
- POST /api/chores - create
- GET /api/chores - list all
- PATCH /api/chores/[id] - update
- DELETE /api/chores/[id] - delete

Validate user role before allowing write operations.
acceptance_criteria:
- All CRUD operations work via API
- Parents can create/edit/delete chores
- Kids can view chores but not modify
- Monetary values stored as cents (integers)
- API returns proper error codes for unauthorized access

title: Implement chore assignment and completion system
description: Create functionality for parents to assign chores to kids on specific dates, and for kids to mark chores as complete.
design:
ChoreAssignmentService methods:
- assignChore(choreId, kidId, date) - parents only
- getAssignmentsForDate(date, kidId?) - all users
- completeChore(assignmentId) - assigned kid or parents
- uncompleteChore(assignmentId) - parents only

API routes:
- POST /api/chore-assignments - assign
- GET /api/chore-assignments?date=YYYY-MM-DD&kidId=X - list
- PATCH /api/chore-assignments/[id]/complete - mark complete
- PATCH /api/chore-assignments/[id]/uncomplete - unmark

Store completion timestamp for payment tracking.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can assign any chore to any kid on any date
- Kids can view their assigned chores
- Kids can mark their own chores complete
- Completion timestamp is recorded
- Can query assignments by date and/or kid
- Real-time updates via Supabase subscriptions

title: Build parent admin UI for chore management
description: Create parent-facing UI for creating/editing chores and assigning them to kids on specific dates.
design:
Parent dashboard pages:
- /admin/chores - List all chores with create/edit/delete actions
- /admin/chores/new - Form to create new chore
- /admin/chores/[id]/edit - Edit existing chore
- /admin/assignments - Calendar/weekly view to assign chores
  - Select kid, date, and chore from dropdowns
  - See what's already assigned

Use shadcn/ui components for forms, tables, and buttons.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can create new chores with name, description, and $ value
- Parents can edit and delete existing chores
- Parents can assign chores to kids for specific dates
- UI is responsive and works on mobile/tablet
- Form validation provides helpful feedback

title: Build kid dashboard with daily chore view
description: Create kid-facing dashboard showing today's assigned chores with ability to mark them complete.
design:
Kid dashboard at /dashboard:
- Shows kid's name and current date
- List of today's assigned chores
- Each chore shows: name, description, $ value, completion status
- Large, touch-friendly "Mark Complete" button
- Visual feedback when marked complete (checkmark, animation)
- Auto-refresh via Supabase real-time subscriptions
- Simple, colorful UI appropriate for kids

Responsive design works on tablets and phones.
acceptance_criteria:
- Kids see their assigned chores for today
- Kids can mark chores complete with one tap
- Completed chores show visual confirmation
- Updates appear in real-time across devices
- UI is kid-friendly and intuitive
- Works well on touch devices

title: Implement recurring chore assignment system
description: Allow parents to create recurring chore assignments (daily, weekly, custom schedule) that auto-generate assignments.
design:
New table: chore_recurrence_rules
- chore_id, kid_id, frequency (daily/weekly/custom), days_of_week, start_date, end_date

ChoreRecurrenceService:
- createRule(choreId, kidId, frequency, days) - parents only
- generateAssignments(date) - background job
- updateRule(id, updates) - parents only
- deleteRule(id) - parents only

Background job runs daily at midnight to generate next day's assignments based on active rules.

Parents can still create ad-hoc assignments that override or supplement recurring ones.
acceptance_criteria:
- Parents can create weekly recurring patterns (e.g., "Kid A does dishes Mon/Wed/Fri")
- Assignments auto-generate daily based on rules
- Parents can edit/delete recurring rules
- Ad-hoc assignments still work
- UI shows which assignments are from recurring rules
- Can temporarily skip a recurring assignment

title: Document architecture decisions and tech stack in docs/ARCHITECTURE.md
description: Create comprehensive architecture documentation covering tech stack decisions, service layer pattern, modularity strategy, and design principles that enable future refactoring (including potential Go migration).
design:
Document should cover:
- Tech stack: Next.js 14+, TypeScript, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- Architecture layers: Frontend → API Client → API Route → Service → Repository → Database
- Service layer pattern and why it enables modularity
- Repository pattern for database abstraction
- Feature-based code organization
- Real-time updates via Supabase subscriptions
- Authentication and authorization strategy
- Calendar integration architecture (native, subscribed, work sync agent)
- PWA setup for multi-device access
- Future refactoring paths (Go microservices, etc.)
- Design principles: modularity, testability, separation of concerns
acceptance_criteria:
- docs/ARCHITECTURE.md file exists
- Covers all major architectural decisions from our planning
- Explains the service layer and repository patterns
- Documents why modularity was prioritized
- Includes diagrams or clear explanations of data flow
- Explains how to extract services to Go later
- Clear enough for new developers to understand the system
